1.Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The site management, partnering with labor leadership, adopted the following policy to govern the operations at the Xerox OKC facility.
While Xerox OKC site management assumes primary responsibility for environmental, health and safety protection, each of us as an employee, contractor, or visitor is also personally responsible to behave in a manner that follows these principles.
?All Xerox OKC activities, products, and services shall be in full compliance with applicable environmental, health and safety regulatory requirements and Xerox Corporate standards.
?All Xerox OKC operations shall be conducted in a manner that minimizes the risk of negative impacts to employee?s health and safety and the environment.
?Xerox OKC shall promote and encourage a healthy and productive workforce.
?Xerox OKC shall strive for continuous improvement of our environmental performance by supporting reduction, reuse, and recycling programs.
This policy is reviewed with all employees and provided to the state environmental regulatory agency each year.

Accidental release prevention is supported through an integrated program that includes monthly work area inspections for all site operations with identified responsible persons and corrective action tracking; incident investigation and review with trend analysis; and an employee driven hazard reporting and tracking system.  Further preventative measures are achieved through the implementation of OSHA?s process safety management (PSM) program developed pursuant to Program 3 status and PSM regulations.

The emergency response planning and preparation procedure, required by ISO 140001, prescribes planning and preparation activities.  Building evacuation and severe weather procedures, which guide site responses to fire, explosion, chemical release, security emergency, and severe weather incidents, are part of the site emergency response plan and further supports the emergency respo

nse planning and preparation procedure.

2.Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
The Xerox OKC site is a stationary source operating under a Title V permit issued by the Oklahoma Department of Environmental Quality?s Air Quality Division, permit number 98-253-TV (M-1).  The regulated manufacturing process uses 1,3-Butadiene to manufacture a styrene/butadiene copolymer.  1,3-Butadiene is listed for its flammable properties only.  All other chemicals used at this facility are either below the concentration or threshold quantity values.

3.Worst-Case Release Scenario and Alternative Release Scenario
The worst-case release scenario assumed storage vessel failure with release of the entire contents and a subsequent vapor cloud explosion.  Administrative controls limit the amount of 1,3-Butadiene, a flammable gas, stored in the vessel.  RMP*Comp, version 1.07, was used to model the distance to the endpoint of 1 psi overpressure.

The alternative release scenario evaluated the impact from loss of process control at the initial stages of the process.  If during the resin manufacturing process, control of the reaction is lost, the entire reactor contents are evacuated to a concrete bunker.  The alternative scenario assumed the release from evacuating the material results in a vapor cloud fire with the endpoint being the Lower Flammability Limit.  Passive or active mitigation measures were not considered in the impact modeling; however, passive mitigation measures include a concrete bunker containment and active mitigation measures include protecting the manufacturing plant with a deluge system, water curtain, and sprinkler system.

4.General Accidental Release Prevention Program
Xerox OKC regulated operations are covered by a Title V air permit that includes compliance with Risk Management Plan requirements and NESHAP MACT Standard Subpart JJJ.  Under Subpart JJJ, the Leak Detection and Repair (LDAR) program is an important component it regularly inspecting and monitorin

g equipment for leaks and conducting repairs in an expeditious manner.  The accidental release prevention program is also bolstered by compliance with OSHA?s PSM requirements.  Further accidental release prevention activities include an extensive preventative maintenance program for the plant.  The PM program includes annual gamma scan with neutron backscatter scanning of the 1,3-Butadiene storage vessel and associated piping and annual pressure vessel recertification. 

5.Five-Year Accident History
Xerox OKC has not experienced any accidents in the past five (5) years that require reporting pursuant to ?68.42(a).

6.Emergency Response Program
Xerox OKC maintains a site emergency response plan that is reviewed annually and communicated with the Oklahoma City Fire Department?s (OKCFD?s) hazardous materials response station and local stations that would respond to an emergency.  In addition to the annual review the OKCFD is given a site tour during all three shifts and emergency response informational packets are provided and carried in each station engine.  Xerox OKC actively participates in the Oklahoma County Local Emergency Planning Committee?s (LEPC?s) routine monthly meetings.  During these meetings Xerox OKC is able to keep the LEPC informed on current activities and also communicate with the Oklahoma County Emergency Management Coordinator.  

The EH&S training plan includes giving employees training in the following areas:  40-hr HAZWOPER, Incident Investigation, Incident Command System, Confined Space Rescue, Medical First Responder, First Aid, Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) and Automatic External Defibrillator (AED), and Incipient Fire Team.  On-site Wellness Center, staffed by a licensed practical nurse, coordinates and trains Medical Emergency Response Team members in the skills necessary to respond to medical emergencies.

At least one drill a year is executed with the site goal of one each quarter.  These drills cover fire evacuation, severe weathe

r shelter-in-place, chemical evacuation, and evacuation to safe rooms for security or chemical release emergencies.  All employees participate in the drills and employees with additional training described above have expanded rolls in mock emergency scenarios and tabletop emergency exercises.

7.Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Xerox OKC has an invested commitment to improving the environmental, health and safety program for the site, as evidenced by our ISO 14001 registration and participation in OSHA?s Voluntary Protection Program as a Merit site.  A strategy has been developed to achieve Star status within a year.  These programs are covered by an environmental management system and safety management system, respectively.  Through these management systems Xerox OKC strives for continuous improvement in our environmental, health and safety program for all operations across the site.
